Award.AbstractNarration:
ISVD 2012 will be the continuation of a highly successful and innovative series of conferences within the geometric modeling and computer graphics disciplines. The eight previous events were held in Tokyo, Japan; Seoul, Korea; Banff, Canada; Kiev, Ukraine; Copenhagen, Denmark; Quebec City, Canada, and Quin Dao, China. While many conferences in the areas of computational geometry, computer graphics and engineering have touched some topics covered by the proposed event, it is only recently that the Voronoi diagram research has formed into a separate discipline and the unique forum on Voronoi Diagrams in Science and Engineering was created.

The goal of the International Conferences on Voronoi Diagrams in Science and Engineering is to concentrate specifically on unique aspects of the research into the Voronoi diagrams and on practical applications of this research to manufacturing engineering, VLSI design, communication, geomatics, GIS (geographical information systems), urban planning, medicine, bioinformatics, high-performance computing, education and other applications. Another unique aspect is that this year will also feature a Voronoi Art Symposium that runs concurrently with the conference and showcases artistic drawings and interpretations of the Voronoi concept. This event, without a doubt, bridges the gap between Sciences and Arts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The notion of Voronoi diagram refers to a conceptually simple geometric construct that is based on a finite set of points in a Euclidean space. Intuitively speaking, it is such a simple notion that it can be described to a non-specialist.  The Voronoi sell of a  particular point is the set is all points that are closer to that point than to any other point in the set.  The Voronoi diagram of the set of points is the collection of the Voronoi cells together with their boundries.  This gives a partitioning of  the Euclidean space into convex polygonal regions. 

It is not surprising that such a simple geometric construct should find numerous practical or theoretical applications in many fields of science. Voronoi diagrams of sets of points in the Euclidean spaces are fundamental geometric constructs. They find natural connections to other fundamental constructs appearing in many applications of Computer Graphics. Over the past few decades the subject of Voronoi diagrams has been flourishing through numerous research articles, turning it into a well-regarded area of computational geometry, with numerous theoretical and practical applications in diverse scientific areas.

The 9th International Symposium on Voronoi Diagrams in Science and Engineering (ISVD) 2012, took place during June 27-29 at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. It was the firrst time this international event was held in the U.S. ISVD 2012 addressed a wide range of research and applications related to Voronoi diagrams. A website was developed to advertise the conference,  http://www.isvd12.rutgers.edu/

The goal of the International Conferences on Voronoi Diagrams in Science and Engineering, ISVD 2012,  was to concentrate specifically on unique aspects of research into the Voronoi diagrams, including   practical  and educational applications of this research. Another unique aspect was to give an introduction to Polynomiography, the art and science of visualization in approximation of zeros of polynomials.  Information about the subject can be found at http://www.cs.rutgers.edu/~kalantar/polynomiography/index.html

The introduction of Polynomiography into the theme of ISVD produces a deeper understanding of fundamental connections between polynomial root-finding and Vornonoi diagrams in the Euclidean plane. This connection was specifically emphasized through a workshop with hands-on activities with its software in a computer lab.  Polynomiography also bridges Sciences and Arts. 

The Voronoi diagram is one of the fundamental mathematical concepts, with numerous applications in the fields of science and engineering. The topics covered by the conference  included a subset of  theoretical aspects of Voronoi diagrams, as well as computational aspects, such as,  the construction of Voronoi diagrams and large-scale computing, generalization of the Voronoi diagram, Voronoi Art, and applications of the concept in biology, chemistry, physics, material sciences, geography, Geographic Information Systems, computer graphics, solid modeling, pattern analysis and recognition, motion analysis and planning, VLSI design, collision detection and avoidance, networking  and communication, medicine, molecular biology, visualization, biometrics and other emerging areas such as Polynomiography.

There is a growing awareness of applications of Voronoi diagrams in science and engineering. The ISVD conference would help further spread of the potential applications in new areas of science and engineering, leading to new discoveries. Furthermore, the newly revealed connections between polynomial root-finding and Polynomiography will inspire new mathematical and algorithmic understanding, new applications, and more fruitful achievements by researchers.
